DOC.HEAD: Former Southern Command Chief Says Military Attack `Well-Planned'
With AM-US-Panama, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The former head of the U.S. Southern Command in Panama, said Wednesday that the military strike against Panama was ``well-planned and well-executed'' even though he has long opposed the use of force there. Retired Gen. Fred Woerner, who left the Southern Command on Sept. 30, also said the operation would be judged ``a disaster, an absolute catastrophe'' if Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega returns to power. Woerner had opposed military intervention in Panama, advocating diplomatic and other peaceful options to dislodge Noriega. The Panamanian leader has been indicted on drug charges in the United States. Various U.S. administrations failed to deal successfully with Noriega, ultimately pushing President Bush into a corner where he could do nothing except send in the military, Woerner said. ``Bush had no other options. It had reached a point where an American was killed,'' he said. Woerner, in a telephone interview from San Jose, Calif., said Bush called for the military strike to protect the lives of Americans and ensure freedom of movement in the Panama Canal. Although he did not have inside knowledge of the military operation, Woerner said it appeared from news reports that it was handled professionally and competently. ``The military operation looked well-planned and well-executed,'' Woerner said, adding, however, that it apparently took longer than expected. Woerner described Noriega as ``a clever, clever guy.'' The U.S. operation won't be considered successful unless Noriega is either captured or driven from Panama and never returns, Woerner said. He said he did not think Bush would call off the operation until it was certain that Noriega could never return to Panama.
